newsitem.title: USA: Bid to block liquor ads gains Koop's support.
newsitem.headline: Bid to block liquor ads gains Koop's support.

text.p: Former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop has lent his support to a petition by Alaska's governor asking the Federal Communications Commission to ban liquor advertisements from radio and television.
Koop sent a letter Monday to FCC Acting Secretary William Caton that endrosed Gov. Tony Knowles' petition, which was filed last month.

"The combined effect of television and hard liquor advertising will, without a doubt, wield an untoward influence on our nation's youth and the millions of Americans who fight alcohol addiction every day of their lives," Koop said in the letter, released Tuesday by Knowles' office.
Knowles on November 19 filed his petition with the FCC after the Distilled Spirits Council lifted its voluntary ban on television and radio advertising.
In his petition, the Democratic governor cited Alaska's notorious alcohol-related woes, which are particularly acute in many Native villages.
